title: 103_s1744
content:
The Act titled "National Commission on Financial Services Act" establishes the National Commission on Financial Services. The National Commission on Financial Services is established with 11 voting members and 6 nonvoting members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, and Majority Leader of the Senate. The National Commission on Financial Services has 11 voting members and 6 nonvoting members appointed by various leaders. Voting members must be users of the financial services system and not government employees. The National Commission on Financial Services has 11 voting members and 6 nonvoting members who are experts in finance. Members are appointed by March 31, 1994, for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The President designates a chairperson from the voting members. The initial meeting must occur within 30 days. The National Commission on Financial Services, consisting of 11 voting members and 6 nonvoting experts in finance, appoints a Chairperson within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are held as called by the Chairperson, with a majority of members forming a quorum for hearings. The National Commission on Financial Services appoints a Chairperson within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are held as called by the Chairperson, with a majority of members forming a quorum for hearings. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is required to conduct a thorough study of the strengths and weaknesses of the US financial services system in meeting the needs of various users, including consumers, businesses, communities, agriculture, governmental entities, and exporters. The study will consider a range of financial services needs. The Commission is mandated to assess the US financial services system's ability to meet diverse user needs, considering economic changes and regulatory policies for consumer protection, competition, and efficient service delivery. The Commission consults with various financial regulatory bodies to ensure efficient and cost-effective implementation of federal policies. The Commission consults with financial regulatory bodies like the Secretary of the Treasury, SEC, CFTC, CBO Director, and Comptroller General. Based on a study, the Commission develops recommendations to improve the US financial services system, including changes to legislative and administrative policies affecting the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and the system's ability to meet user needs. The Commission conducts a study on the financial services system, focusing on user needs, system safety, costs, competitiveness of providers, fund allocation, and reports its findings and recommendations to key government officials by January 20, 1995. The Commission is granted powers under Section 4 to carry out its study on the financial services system and report its findings and recommendations to government officials by January 20, 1995. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, obtain official data from federal departments, use postal services, and accept gifts or donations. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on the level IV of the Executive Schedule for their daily duties. Government officers or employees serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided to Commission members at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for these personnel can be determined by the Chairperson without adhering to standard pay rate regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for personnel must not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Administrative support services can be provided by the Administrator of General Services upon request. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 6. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will end 30 days after submitting the required report. All records will be sent to the National Archives.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for this Act are authorized to be appropriated. These funds will be available without a fiscal year limit.
